Dear Lauren M Skinner:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 06/27/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Vivian D Malleck, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4114-1 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers.
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,
that each employee and volunteer who has contact
with residents 4 or more hours per week for more than
2 consecutive weeks is free from communicable

tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1 year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the
last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of thirty-eight employee files reviewed did not have documentation that the
employee is free from communicable tuberculosis.
CCI Rule 400.4515 Electrical installations.
(2) In an existing facility, electrical wiring and
equipment acceptable at the time these rules take
effect shall continue to be approved until the facility or
portion thereof is remodeled or converted. When an
existing facility or portion thereof is remodeled or
converted, only that portion remodeled or converted
need comply with subrule (1) of this rule. Electrical
services shall be maintained in a safe condition. When
conditions indicate a need for inspection, the electrical
services shall be inspected by a licensed electrical
inspection service. A copy of the inspection report shall
be maintained at the facility for review. Any areas cited
in the report shall be corrected and a new electrical
system inspection shall be obtained verifying the
corrections have been made.
Qualified Fire Inspector stated the following in his report, “Make the necessary repairs
to the electrical outlet in the Main dining hall to minimize the possibility of electrical
shock.”
CCI Rule 400.4535 Fire alarm.
(4) Fire alarm systems and devices in existing facilities
shall be maintained in proper working order and shall
continue to be approved until the facility is remodeled
or converted.
Qualified Fire Inspector stated the following in his report, “Replace missing smoke
detector in the sleeping room.”
CCI Rule 400.4543 Doors.
(4) Interior doors to any enclosure which is required to
have not less than a 1-hour fire resistance rating shall
be B-labeled fire doors in labeled frames and shall be

equipped with positive latching hardware and self-
closing devices.
Qualified Fire Inspector stated the following in his report, “Replace the door latching
devices and provide appropriate working self-closing devices on all doors leading to
the janitors [sic] closets, mop rooms and sleeping rooms as needed throughout the
second and third floor use areas.”
CCI Rule 400.4560 Cooking appliances.
(3)(d) In a newly constructed, remodeled or converted
large and secure facility, where metal hoods or
canopies are provided over commercial kitchen
cooking appliances, they shall be designed and
equipped in compliance with the national fire protection
association standard No. 96, entitled “Standard for
Ventilation Control and Fire Protection of Commercial
Cooking Operations,“ 2014, and shall comply with all of
the following requirements: (d) Fire extinguishment
equipment for the hood and exhaust duct of a cooking
appliance in a kitchen shall be in compliance with the
national fire protection association standard No. 96,
entitled “Standard for Ventilation Control and Fire
Protection of Commercial Cooking Operations”.
Qualified Fire Inspector stated the following in his report, “Have the hood extinguishing
system serviced and tagged bi-annually by a certified hood extinguishing system
technician. The extinguishing system service just expired as it is due every six months.”
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Wolverine Center received a rating - C on their fire inspection completed on
06/09/2025. Qualified Fire Inspector (QFI) stated the citations appear to be from
youth property destruction and not due to a lack of maintenance. QFI provided
temporary approval until 08/09/2025 to correct the citations. Wolverine Center is
expected to provide Division of Child Welfare a fire inspection report with a rating
- A by 08/09/2025 or a special investigation will be initiated.
• R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio. (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise
outside of the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-
on checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks shall not
exceed fifteen minutes. Wolverine Center prints their own spiral bound logbook
for use. The shift head count grid in the logbook has preprinted minutes that are
in fifteen-minute increments with space for staff to document the hour. Moving
forward Wolverine Center staff are expected to document and complete variable

eye-on checks that do not exceed fifteen minutes during sleeping hours. This rule
was not cited because this issue was not previously cited and in the bottom left
corner of the shift head count grid logbook page is the date 11/07/2023 denoting
the date the form has been in use.
• Physical management incident reports are to be entered in the Child Welfare
Licensing Module system within 24 hours and then reviewed and approved by a
supervisor within 72 hours of the physical management.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Wolverine Center has a variance is for a nine-year-old youth placed at Wolverine
Center. Wolverine Center is expected to notify Division of Child Welfare
Licensing on the day this youth is replaced or request another variance prior to
the current variance expiration date of 07/29/2025.
• Wolverine Center has a variance to staff the Mental Health Behavioral
Stabilization program with one staff to three youths to allocate staff resources to
the shelter program due to youth needs. Program office supports this temporary
change. Wolverine Center is to request another staff to youth ratio variance or
return to one staff to two youth for their Mental Health Behavioral Stabilization
program prior to the variance expiration date of 07/31/2025.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 2 substantiated incidents during this licensing period as follows:
• 2025SIC0000236 completed on 01/31/2025 cited Rule 400.4158 (1)(a)(ii)
when a staff improperly restrained a youth. Corrective action plan (CAP)
was approved on 02/25/2025. The staff, who performed the improper
restraint in this investigation, was placed on administrative leave and
subsequently terminated. Wolverine Center staff received Employee
Assistance Program information. CAP is still being monitored for staff
review and sign off of youth safety plans and the retraining and use of
proper behavior management techniques.
• 2025SIC0000178 completed on 01/31/2025 cited Rule 400.4158 (1)(a)(ii)
when a staff improperly restrained a youth. Corrective action plan (CAP)
was approved on 02/25/2025. The staff, who performed the improper
restraint in this investigation, was placed on administrative leave and
subsequently terminated. Wolverine Center staff received Employee
Assistance Program information. CAP is still being monitored for staff

review and sign off of youth safety plans and the retraining and use of
proper behavior management techniques.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted 5 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• Interim inspection completed on 09/12/2024 cited the agency for Rule
400.4128 (4)(h) because 3 of forty staff did not have Standard First Aid
training. CAP approved 10/23/2024 stated Wolverine Center would utilize
another program to notify staff of trainings. Wolverine Center switched to
another program and Standard First Aid training was completed by all staff
during this renewal inspection. The goal of this CAP is met.
• 2025SIC0000194 completed on 03/26/2025 cited Rule 400.4109 (1)(c)
when a staff failed to write an incident report about his physical
interactions with a youth. Rule 400.4131 was also cited when a staff, who
witnessed the physical interaction, did not report it. CAP approved on
04/23/2025 is being monitored for retraining staff on when to write an
incident report and review of mandated reporting.
• 2025SIC0000470 completed on 04/04/2024 cited Rule 400.4126 when a
staff admitted to falling asleep on duty. CAP approved on 05/02/2025 is
being monitored for review of job expectations, which includes no sleeping
on duty. Also, the staff, who fell asleep on duty, was suspended for 3 days.
• 2025SIC0000350 was completed on 04/08/2025 cited Rule 400.4158
(1)(a)(ii) when a staff pushed a youth. CAP approved on 05/27/2025 is
being monitored for review and discussion on how staff are to manage the
environment in escalated situations.
• 2025SIC0000366 was completed on 05/05/2025 cited Rule 400.4159 (5)
when staff performed a supine restraint without the authorization of a
supervisor. CAP approved on 06/10/2025 is being monitored for staff
retraining on the protocols for a supine restraint. CAP is also being
monitored for supervisors to review restraint videos within 72 hours of the
restraint and video review and follow up with staff involved in the restraint.
The staff, who performed the supine restraint, was terminated.
Financial Overview
Wolverine Center's 2023 annual financial audit and budget were reviewed. There
are no concerns. Wolverine Center's 2024 annual financial audit and budget is still
in the works.

PREA compliance (if applicable)
This is not applicable to Wolverine Center.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment completed on 06/30/2025 was reviewed. Report
highlights Wolverine Center’s new system for human resource and staff
development functions. This new system is user friendly and provides timely
notifications for required trainings, which assisted in rule compliance and staff
development. Wolverine Center continues to hold mandatory biweekly staff
meetings facilitated by a combination of the chief administrator, program manager
and supervisors. These meetings discuss areas of concerns, policy and
procedures and address corrective action plans. Staff are also required to review
and sign off on the written meeting notes.
Chief Administrator stated on 06/05/2025 at the renewal entrance meeting that
Wolverine Center’s level system and youth handbook are being revised with a
01/2026 target implementation date.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were selected for interviews on 06/05/2025 at Wolverine Center. Each
staff correctly explained the youth grievance procedure, mandated reporting and
the physical management model used at Wolverine Center. When asked what they
would change about Wolverine Center, only one staff provided a suggestion. This
staff stated the landscaping around the building and the playground area could be
spruced up.
Four youths were selected for interviews on 06/05/2025 at Wolverine Center. Each
youth stated they participated in group meetings and routinely met with their social
service worker. Each youth stated they attended school, had adequate food, made
phone calls to approved persons and did not express concerns with their
placement at Wolverine Center. When asked what they would change about
Wolverine Center only one youth provided a suggestion. This youth expressed a
desire for more outings, but was unable to provide an example.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of Wolverine Center was completed on 06/05/2025. Wolverine
Center's administrative offices, kitchen, dining area, youth bedrooms and
bathrooms, recreation rooms, laundry room, staff lounge, classrooms and
gymnasium were found to be clean and orderly.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
